key_insight: An exploratory randomized controlled trial (N=165, five UK secondary schools) indicates that LearnLM — a generative model fine-tuned for pedagogy and deployed via chat-based tutoring on the Eedi platform — can support students safely and effectively in classroom math instruction.
problem_solved: Addresses the scalability gap of one-to-one personalized tutoring by exploring whether generative AI can provide effective, safe, and classroom-ready tutoring support.
method: Conducted an exploratory RCT with 165 students across five UK secondary schools using integrated chat-based tutoring on the Eedi mathematics platform.
Deployed LearnLM, a generative model fine-tuned for pedagogy, to run tutoring sessions alongside classroom instruction and monitoring.
Evaluated outcomes and safety through classroom deployment and controlled comparison (pre/post and between-group measures) to assess learning impact and potential risks.
impact: Provides evidence that pedagogy-focused fine-tuning plus careful classroom evaluation can yield practical, safe AI tutoring—encouraging ML practitioners to prioritize domain-specific tuning, rigorous field trials (e.g., RCTs), and safety guardrails when building educational models.
visual_elements: Study flow diagram: recruitment → randomization → chat-based tutoring sessions → outcome assessment (N=165, 5 schools)
Before/after or between-group bar chart showing relative learning gains (annotated, without exact numbers if unavailable)
Icon trio showing model (LearnLM) + platform (Eedi) + classroom (teacher + students) to convey deployment context
Safety checklist/infographic highlighting key safeguards (human oversight, monitoring, pedagogy fine-tuning)
paper_title: AI tutoring can safely and effectively support students: An exploratory RCT in UK classrooms
paper_authors: LearnLM Team, Eedi, :, Albert Wang, Aliya Rysbek
